column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Measure Your Child 's Pupillary Distance for Eyeglasses
#Text=Pupillary distance , or PD , is the measurement of distance in millimeter between the pupils .
#Text=This information allows opticians to place the optical center of the lenses directly in front of the pupils , allowing for the best vision possible .
#Text=PD is often included on a prescription .
#Text=If the measurement is not included , it is easy to measure for yourself or your child .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Starting Out
#Text=Note the average pupillary distance for children .
#Text=This measurement ranges from 41 to 53 millimeters .
#Text=Choose an appropriate measuring option for your child .
#Text=There are three options that you may choose from , to get the measurement you need :
#Text=Measuring PD on a Child who Wears Glasses
#Text=Have your child put on their glasses .
#Text=Ask the child to cover one eye .
#Text=Have them look at an object that is at least 20 feet away .
#Text=For example , the child could sit inside and focus on a tree or building out of the window .
#Text=Obtain a non-permanent marker .
#Text=Place a single dot on the lens over the center of the pupil .
#Text=Repeat this process with the other eye .
#Text=Ensure that the process was completed correctly .
#Text=With both eyes open , the child should see the dots overlap when they are looking through their marked glasses at a distant object .
#Text=Remove the glasses .
#Text=Measure the distance between the two dots with a millimeter ( mm ) ruler .
#Text=Measuring the PD
#Text=if Your Child Does Not Wear Glasses
#Text=Have your child look at an object that is at least 20 feet away .
#Text=Again , they could sit inside and focus on a tree or building outside .
#Text=Take a millimeter ( mm ) ruler and measure the distance from the center of one pupil to the center of the other pupil .
#Text=Checking your measurement for accuracy .
#Text=You can make this measure even more accurate by taking a flashlight and shining it in your child ’s eyes .
#Text=The reflection on the pupils will help you to find the center of the pupils .
#Text=When doing this , make sure that the child continues to look at the distant object .
#Text=Repeat the measurement two more times .
#Text=Whether you are using a flashlight or not , take this measurement at least three times to ensure that your measurements are consistent .
#Text=Measuring the PD
#Text=if Your Child has an Eye Muscle Imbalance
#Text=Understand the term eye muscle imbalance .
#Text=This imbalance can be the result of some form strabismus .

#Text=This is a condition the results in an abnormal alignment of the eye , typically causing one to squint , the eyes to cross , or the inability for both eyes to focus on an object at the same time. .
#Text=Extropia is a condition where one or both eyes tend to turn outward .
#Text=Esotropia is a strabismus condition where one eye focuses inward .
#Text=Try to obtain the pupillary distance from your optician or doctor .
#Text=If this is not an option , this is how you take the measurement .
#Text=If your child ’s eyes turn inward or outward when looking at distance , cover one eye and have them look at an object that is at least 20 feet away with the uncovered eye .
#Text=For example , they could sit inside and focus on a tree or building outside .
#Text=It is important that the child ’s pupils are facing forward when you take this measurement .
#Text=Take the measurement in millimeters from the center of the bridge of the nose to the center of the pupil .
#Text=By doubling this measurement , you will get an accurate measurement of the distance PD .
#Text=Note : You only need to take this measurement for one eye , not both .
#Text=Obtaining the Measurement from an Optician
#Text=Use the most comfortable method .
#Text=For young customers receiving their first pair of glasses , getting the measurement from an optician is the easiest method .
#Text=As well , it is the best method if you are ordering glasses for a child with an eye muscle imbalance ( strabismus ) .
#Text=Most opticians will measure PD for free or a small fee .
#Text=Measure a child with Strabismus .
#Text=In the event that you are unable to get the measurement from a doctor or optician , you can take the measurements yourself , as outlined above .
#Text=You will need to ensure that your child ’s pupils are facing forward when you take the measurement .
#Text=Locating Pupillary Distance on a Prescription ( Rx )
#Text=Understand the PD can be written a number of ways :
#Text=A single PD number is measured from pupil to pupil .
#Text=Average PD measurements for kids are between 41 and 53 .
#Text=The second method results in two PD numbers ( one for each eye ) and is called a ‘ Monocular PD ’ .
#Text=This is a measurement from each pupil to the center of the face .
#Text=Average measurements for kids are between 20 and 27 , for each side .
#Text=Reading an optician 's prescription .
#Text=A prescription can also have two PD numbers .
#Text=One PD is for close vision and reading , while the other is for distance .
#Text=The PD for close vision and reading will typically be 3 mm less than the distance PD reading .
